data.title: TIFF Photos 2015: THR's Portfolio With Sandra Bullock, Patrick Stewart, Jessica Chastain and More
data.meta_description: The Toronto Film Festival didn't yield a definitive frontrunner, but it did begin a fast and furious awards conversation as strong showings and buzzworthy stars (shot here) stormed the starting line.
data.text:
‘Our Brand Is Crisis’

Scott McNairy, Grant Heslov, Sandra Bullock, Zoe Kazan and director David Gordon Green of Our Brand is Crisis, the thinly veiled satire about political strategists.

Read the review

‘Our Brand Is Crisis’

Said director David Gordon Green of the film, "What I think it does do is bring an entertaining light to the conversation of American involvement in international politics."

Read more David Gordon Green: 'Our Brand Is Crisis' Was Not Made "With Any Sort of Political Agenda" (Q&A)

‘About Ray’

The transgender drama casts Elle Fanning as the title character who is transitioning from female to male, and Naomi Watts as her single mother.

See more TIFF 2015: 30 World Premieres to Watch

‘The Martian’

Jessica Chastain told THR of shooting The Martian, "I got to let my inner geek fly."

See more Jessica Chastain Hopes 'The Martian' Helps Recruit Female Astronauts to "Go to Mars"

‘Beasts of No Nation’

Director Cary Fukunaga of Beasts of No Nation, which stars Idris Elba as a warlord who recruits an army of child soldiers in an unspecified African country.

See more TIFF: Cary Fukunaga Says ‘Beasts of No Nation’ Is Not an Issue Film

‘Freeheld’

Ellen Page, Julianne Moore and Michael Shannon of Freeheld, which sees Moore as the late Laurel Hester, a police detective who fought government officials for equal treatment when she was diagnosed with cancer, and Page as her partner who was denied Hester's pension benefits.

See more TIFF 2015: 30 World Premieres to Watch

‘Freeheld’

Said Ellen Page of Freeheld, "What the film does is just makes it so personal, and really focuses on a couple that are middle and lower-middle class, and in a situation where not having these rights, … it really affected their life."

See more 'Freeheld' Star Julianne Moore Says LGBT Discrimination Rooted in Distance, Not Hate

‘Freeheld’

Freeheld screenwriter Ron Nyswaner.

‘Freeheld’

Michael Shannon said of portraying Dane Wells, "Just because he doesn't wear his heart on his sleeve doesn't mean he's not got one."

See more 'Freeheld' Star Julianne Moore Says LGBT Discrimination Rooted in Distance, Not Hate

‘Everest’

Baltasar Kormakur, director of Everest, which stars Jake Gyllenhaal and Josh Brolin in the big-screen account of the disastrous 1996 trek to the summit of the world's tallest mountain.

Read more 'Everest' Stars, Director Talk Isolation, Responsibility of Filming Real-Life Mountain Saga

‘Green Room’

Alia Shawkat, Imogen Poots, director Jeremy Saulnier, Patrick Stewart and Anton Yelchin of Green Room, which presents a gory confrontation between punk rockers and white supremacists.

Read the review

‘Green Room’

Said Jeremy Saulnier of Green Room, "I see this as a batshit crazy punk rock horror thriller."

Read more It's Skinheads vs. Punks in the Hardcore 'Green Room'

‘Green Room’

Patrick Stewart plays the Neo-Nazis' Gruppenfuhrer in the film.

‘Green Room’

Anton Yelchin plays the idealistic bassist of the group.

‘Green Room’

Alia Shawkat is the lead guitarist, Sam, of the band.

‘Green Room’

Imogen Poots breaks out an American accent to play Amber in Green Room.

‘Sicario’

Josh Brolin, Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro of Sicario, Denis Villeneuve's thriller about the inter-American drug trade.

Read the review

‘Trumbo’

In Trumbo, Bryan Cranston stars as Dalton Trumbo, the blacklisted 1940s screenwriter who was also a member of the Communist Party and worked to secretly pen scripts for Hollywood classics like Roman Holiday and Spartacus.

Read more Bryan Cranston Goes From Drug Lord to Communist in Blacklist Saga 'Trumbo': "A Socialist, But He Loved Being Rich"

‘Trumbo’

Trumbo director Jay Roach.

‘Land of Mine’

Emil and Oscar Belton, director Martin Zandvliet, Roland Moller, Mikkel Boe Folsgaard, cinematographer Camilla Hjelm Knusden and producer Mikael Rieks of Land of Mine,the World War II drama about German prisoners put to work defusing land mines along the coast of Denmark.

Read the review

‘Land of Mine’

Mikkel Boe Folsgaard of Land of Mine.

‘Land of Mine’

Camilla Hjelm Knusden, cinematographer of Land of Mine.

Read more From 'The Martian' to 'Truth,' Todd McCarthy's 5 Most Tantalizing Titles at TIFF

‘Land of Mine’

Danish director Martin Zandvliet helms the story portraying a true but not well-known part of history.

‘Land of Mine’

Roland Moller plays Danish Sergeant Rasmussen, who is assigned to train and oversee the German prisoners. Most of them are teenage boys conscripted by Hitler in the last days of the war, and they are hopelessly ill equipped to carry out their dangerous job.

‘Born to Dance’

Tia Maipi, Parris Goebe and Stan Walker of Born to Dance, following a hip-hop dance crew through a regional competition.

‘Hardcore’

Director Ilya Naishuller, Sharlto Copley, Ekaterina Kononenko, Timur Bekmambetov and Inga Vainshtein Smith of Hardcore, a fast-paced first-person sci-fi action thriller inspired by a music video.

Read the review

‘Hardcore’

Hardcore director Ilya Naishuller said, "It’s not just a camera getting thrown off a building. It’s a guy holding a camera, getting thrown off the side of a building. All the stunts are real."

‘Hardcore’

Hardcore actress Ekaterina Kononenko.

‘Hardcore’

Sharlto Copley of Hardcore.

‘Hardcore’

Darya Charnska of Hardcore.

‘Hardcore’

Hardcore star Inga Vainshtein Smith.

‘February’

Lucy Boynton, director Osgood Perkins and Kiernan Shipka of February, the horror-thriller that tells the story of Joan, a haunted and beautiful girl who pilgrimages in winter to a prestigious all-girls prep school, and Rose and Kat, two students who are stranded when their parents fail to pick them up for winter vacation. As Joan approaches the school, Rose watches as Kat has horrific visions and becomes possessed.

‘February’

"The weather condition throughout was quite tense. It was February and March in Ottawa. I think that kind of added to the affect of it being an intense sort of film,” said Kiernan Shipka of making February.

See more TIFF: Director Says ‘February’ Was “A Very Big Leap” for What Kiernan Shipka is Known For

‘February’

"It's rich and layered with all of these other emotions. Yes, it's drenched in blood, but it has so much more to offer the audience," said Lucy Boynton of the horror-thriller.

See more TIFF: Director Says ‘February’ Was “A Very Big Leap” for What Kiernan Shipka is Known For

‘February’

"I wanted to make sure it went against the grain of horror films, which obviously have a tendency to be very aggressive. … I wanted this to have a more elegant, composed and thoughtful feeling to it."

See more TIFF: Director Says ‘February’ Was “A Very Big Leap” for What Kiernan Shipka is Known For

‘Women He’s Undressed’

Director Gillian Armstrong of Women He’s Undressed, which chronicles the life and loves of Orry-Kelly, the Australian costume designer of 42nd Street and Casablanca.

Read the review

‘The Danish Girl’

Alicia Vikander, director Tom Hooper and Eddie Redmayne of The Danish Girl, the bio-drama of groundbreaking transgender figure Lili Elbe and the artist wife who stood by her husband Einar Wegener throughout his long and difficult transition to live as a woman.

Read the review

‘The Danish Girl’

"One of the things that’s interesting in Man Into Woman, is that Lili talks about herself in the third person sometimes," said Redmayne of the book that contained Lili Elbe's letters.

Read more TIFF: Eddie Redmayne, Tom Hooper Explain Why They Kept the Controversial Language in 'Danish Girl'

‘The Danish Girl’

Alicia Vikander portrays Gerda Wegener, the artist wife who accepts her husband's transgender transition.

See more TIFF: ‘The Danish Girl’ Star Alicia Vikander Chooses Roles “That Bring Out a Bit of Fear”

‘The Danish Girl’

"I think it’s yet another example of how kind of extraordinarily modern Gerda is in her brilliant understanding of the journey," said director Tom Hooper of Vikander's character.

Read more TIFF: Eddie Redmayne, Tom Hooper Explain Why They Kept the Controversial Language in 'Danish Girl'

‘The Daughter’

Paul Schneider, Odessa Young and Geoffrey Rush of The Daughter.

Read the review

‘The Daughter’

"I’m old enough now that I’m working with people who are decades younger than I am," Daughter star Geoffrey Rush said. "I still think I’m twenty-one. You just write the rule book yourself."

See more TIFF: ‘The Daughter’ Star Geoffrey Rush Says Dir. Stone “Is a Classicist, but Fresh and Alive"

‘The Daughter’

Paul Schneider of The Daughter.

‘The Daughter’

Daughter director Simon Stone.

See more TIFF: ‘The Daughter’ Star Geoffrey Rush Says Dir. Stone “Is a Classicist, but Fresh and Alive"

‘The Daughter’

Odessa Young of The Daughter.

‘River’

Rossif Sutherland and director Jamie Dagg of River, the thriller that follows an American volunteer doctor in Laos after he is accused of murder, because he intervened in the sexual assault of a young woman.

‘River’

Rossif Sutherland of River.

‘River’

Jamie Dagg makes his directorial feature debut.

‘He Named Me Malala’

Producers Laurie MacDonald, Walter Parkes and director Davis Guggenheim of the documentary He Named Me Malala.

See more TIFF: 'He Named Me Malala' Helmer Davis Guggenheim Wants 'Inconvenient Truth'-Like Reaction

‘Equals’

Kristen Stewart and director Drake Doremus of Equals, the sci-fi romance about two citizens infected with a syndrome that allows human feeling in a society where it's been outlawed.

Read the review

‘I Saw the Light’

Writer-director Marc Abraham, Tom Hiddleston and Elizabeth Olsen of I Saw the Light, the biopic zooming in on country music legend Hank Williams.

Read the review

‘I Saw the Light’

"He said the sunset in the evening was the lonesomest time of the day, and I wanted to know why, why he felt so alone," I Saw the Light star Tom Hiddleston says of Hank Williams.

See more TIFF: ‘I Saw the Light’ Star Tom Hiddleston Says “Hank Williams Was Unknowable”

‘I Saw the Light’

"She was notoriously unliked as a person, but I also had an immense amount of compassion and empathy for her — she was just a woman who had an opinion and gave it," said Elizabeth Olsen of portraying Hank Williams' wife Audrey.

See more Loki vs. Scarlet Witch? Tom Hiddleston, Elizabeth Olsen Debate 'Avengers' Showdown at TIFF

‘Len and Company’

Director Tim Godsall, Jack Kilmer, Kier Gilchrist and Rhys Ifans of Len and Company, which follows a legendary, reclusive music producer who surprisingly reunites with his estranged son.

Read the review

‘Len and Company’

Rhys Ifans said of the younger cast, "It was a real revelation working with them. They do it with such ease. My generation have a tendency to really overcomplicate stuff."

See more TIFF: ‘Len and Company’ Star Rhys Ifans Says of Costars “Nothing Felt Acted. It Was Infectious"

‘Len and Company’

Len and Company actor Jack Kilmer, who plays Len's son and aspiring musician, Max.

‘Len and Company’

Director Tim Godsall, who makes his directorial feature debut.

‘Len and Company’

Kier Gilchrist of Len and Company.

‘Into the Forest’

Ellen Page, Evan Rachel Wood and writer/director Patricia Rozema of Into the Forest, about two sisters as they struggle to survive after the collapse of society in a not-too-distant future.

See more Ellen Page Says "Financing a Movie with Two Female Leads Is Just Harder"

‘Into the Forest’

Said Evan Rachel Wood of Into the Forest, "Unlike other apocalyptic films … this is a really realistic portrayal if every luxury you had was taken away from you."

See more Ellen Page Says "Financing a Movie with Two Female Leads Is Just Harder"

‘Colonia’

Producer Benjamin Herrmann, Daniel Bruhl, Michael Nyqvist and director Florian Gallenberger of Colonia, the Chilean military coup drama that stars Emma Watson as a woman who finds herself in a cult to rescue her boyfriend.

Read the review

‘Colonia’

Daniel Bruhl of Colonia.

‘Colonia’

Michael Nyqvist plays he evil ex-Nazi, Paul Schafer, who runs the Colonia Dignidad religious and agricultural settlement with an iron fist.

‘Truth’

Writer-director James Vanderbilt and Elisabeth Moss of Truth, the Dan Rather scandal drama which stars Robert Redford as the disgraced anchor who reported that George W. Bush had received special treatment while serving in the Air National Guard during the Vietnam War.

Read the review

‘Truth’

Truth writer-director James Vanderbilt.

‘Kill Your Friends’

Director Owen Harris, Ed Skrein, Nicholas Hoult and John Niven of the dark comedy Kill Your Friends.

Read the review

‘Kill Your Friends’

John Niven of Kill Your Friends.

‘Kill Your Friends’

Kill Your Friends director Owen Harris.

‘Youth’

Harvey Kietel, Madalina Ghenea, Paul Dano, Rachel Weisz and Michael Caine of Youth, following two aging artist friends with different ideas about how to wrap up their creative careers.

Read the review

‘Youth’

"If you're young, don't be afraid," said Michael Caine of shooting Youth. "If you're old, be happy."

See more TIFF: Michael Caine Says ‘Youth’ Tells Us “If You’re Young, Don’t Be Afraid"

‘Youth’

Youth actress Madalina Ghenea.

‘Youth’

Harvey Keitel of Youth.

‘Youth’

"To be a still fairly young person doing this to be on set watching these guys [Michael Caine, Harvey Keitel] not just work but work hard and search and care and play and also have fun and I think, be happy is truly inspiring," Youth star Paul Dano said of his older costars.

See more TIFF: Michael Caine Says ‘Youth’ Tells Us “If You’re Young, Don’t Be Afraid"

‘The Man Who Knew Infinity’

Jeremy Irons plays mentor G.H. Hardy in The Man Who Knew Infinity, which stars Dev Patel portraying self-taught math genius Srinivasa Ramanujan.

‘Five Nights in Maine’

Rosie Perez, David Oyelowo and writer-director Maris Curran of Five Nights in Maine, which stars Oyelowo as an African-American widower and Dianne Wiest as his cancer-stricken mother-in-law.

Read the review

‘Five Nights in Maine’

The relationship between "an African-American man and this older white woman over something they have intrinsically in common, but they have nothing in common — I thought that was really great ground for exploration," said Five Nights in Maine star David Oyelowo.

See more TIFF: ‘Five Nights in Maine’ Star David Oyelowo "Loved the Possibility of [the] Relationship”

‘Five Nights in Maine’

Five Nights in Maine actress Rosie Perez.

See more TIFF: ‘Five Nights in Maine’ Star David Oyelowo "Loved the Possibility of [the] Relationship”

‘Sunset Song’

Kevin Guthrie, Agynes Deyn and director Terence Davies of Sunset Song, an independent-minded young woman living on a farm in the years preceding World War I.

Read the review

‘Sunset Song’

Model-turned-actress Agyness Deyn plays Chris Guthrie, a bright farm girl who dreams of becoming a teacher.

‘Sunset Song’

Sunset Song director Terence Davies.

‘Sunset Song’

Sunset Song actor Kevin Guthrie.

‘The Devil’s Candy’

Ethan Embry and director Sean Bryne of The Devil’s Candy, about a struggling painter who is possessed after he moves his family into their dream home in Texas.

‘The Devil’s Candy’

The Devil’s Candy star Ethan Embry.

‘The Lobster’

Director Yorgos Lanthimos and Rachel Weisz of The Lobster, the Colin Farrell-starrer about a future world where people are forced to couple up or be turned into animals.

Read the review

‘The Lobster’

The Lobster director Yorgos Lanthimos.

‘The Lobster’ and ‘Youth’

Rachel Weisz is doing double duty at the fest, with both The Lobster and Youth screening in Toronto.

‘This Changes Everything’

Journalist Naomi Klein and director Avi Lewis of climate change documentary This Changes Everything.

Read the review

‘This Changes Everything’

This Changes Everything Avi Lewis and Naomi Klein.

‘This Changes Everything’

Naomi Klein narrates the climate change doc.

‘This Changes Everything’

This Changes Everything director Avi Lewis.

‘The Dressmaker’

Kate Winslet of The Dressmaker, the revenge dramedy about a talented couturier who returns after many years in Europe to her small Australian outback hometown, from which she fled as a child after being accused of murder.

Read the review

‘The Dressmaker’

Liam Hemsworth of The Dressmaker.

See more TIFF: ‘The Dressmaker’ Star Liam Hemsworth Says Australian Sense of Humor is “Really Sarcastic”

‘The Dressmaker’

"It's quintessentially Australian in a way because it's quite funny, there are some very strange characters in it, but it's got a lot of heart and quite a bit of venom as well," director Jocelyn Moorhouse of The Dressmaker.

See more TIFF: ‘The Dressmaker’ Star Liam Hemsworth Says Australian Sense of Humor is “Really Sarcastic”

‘Desierto’

Producer Alfonso Cuaron, director/co-writer Jonas Cuaron, co-writer Carlos Cuaron and actor Gael Garcia Bernal of Desierto, which follows an illegal immigrant who tries to cross over from Mexican into the U.S., but run afoul of a man (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) who has taken up border patrol duties in his own racist hands.

Read the review

‘Desierto’

Gael Garcia Bernal of Desierto.

See more TIFF: 'Desierto' Star Gael Garcia Bernal Calls Donald Trump's Border Wall "The Most Stupid Investment Ever"

‘Miss You Already’

Director Catherine Hardwicke and Toni Collette of Miss You Already, which stars Collette and Drew Barrymore as as best friends whose relationship is strained when one of them becomes pregnant and the other is diagnosed with cancer.

Read the review

‘Miss You Already’

Director Catherine Hardwicke of Miss You Already.

See more TIFF: Toni Collette Says Meeting Drew Barrymore Was "An Electric Moment"

‘Brooklyn’

Brooklyn actress Saoirse Ronan.

‘Brooklyn’

Brooklyn actor Domhnall Gleeson.

‘Brooklyn’

Brooklyn director John Crowley.

Hyena Road

Hyena Road writer-director Paul Gross.

‘The Meddler’

Director Lorene Scafaria and J.K. Simmons of The Meddler, the dramedy that centers on Susan Sarandon as a recent widow and eternal optimist, who moves from New Jersey to Los Angeles to be closer to her daughter (Rose Byrne).

‘The Meddler’

The Meddler actor J.K. Simmons.

See more TIFF: ‘The Meddler’ Director Says Mom "Was Just So Excited Susan Sarandon Was Playing Her"

‘The Meddler’

The Meddler writer-director Lorene Scafaria joked of Simmons, "It takes a girl with daddy issues to watch Whiplash and say, 'Gosh that guy is really sexy. I think we should make him a love interest.'"

See more TIFF: ‘The Meddler’ Director Says Mom "Was Just So Excited Susan Sarandon Was Playing Her"

‘I Smile Back’

Sarah Silverman, novelist Amy Koppleman, screenwriter Paige Dylan and director Adam Salky of I Smile Back, looking at a wife and mother's battle with self-destructive depression.

Read the review

‘I Smile Back’

"I have experience with depression in my life and I don’t have a problem with addiction, but I’m a comedian and I’m surrounded by it, so I had a lot of resources," said Sarah Silverman of relating to I Smile Back.

See more TIFF: ‘I Smile Back’ Star Sarah Silverman Says Her “Performance is So Good”

‘Black Mass’

David Harbour, Joel Edgerton, Rory Cochrane, Jesse Plemons, Peter Sarsgaard, Julianne Nicholson, Dakota Johnson and director Scott Cooper of Black Mass, which stars Johnny Depp as infamous criminal Whitey Bulger.

Read the review

‘Black Mass’

Joel Edgerton of Black Mass.

See more TIFF: 'Black Mass' Cast Talks Johnny Depp

‘Black Mass’

"How seamlessly he could slip back and forth into a complex character," Jesse Plemons said of Black Mass star Johnny Depp.

See more TIFF: 'Black Mass' Cast Talks Johnny Depp

‘Black Mass’

Director Scott Cooper of Black Mass.

See more TIFF: 'Black Mass' Cast Talks Johnny Depp

‘Black Mass’

Julianne Nicholson of Black Mass.

‘Black Mass’

David Harbour of Black Mass.

See more TIFF: 'Black Mass' Cast Talks Johnny Depp

‘Black Mass’

Peter Sarsgaard of Black Mass.

‘Black Mass’

Rory Cochrane of Black Mass.

See more TIFF: 'Black Mass' Cast Talks Johnny Depp

‘Spotlight’

The journalists, actors and creatives of Spotlight unite: Brian d'Arcy James, Matt Carroll, Michael Rezendes, Sacha Pfeiffer, Rachel McAdams, Tom McCarthy, John Slattery, Walter Robinson, Josh Singer, Ben Bradlee Jr., Liev Schreiber and Marty Baron.

Read the review

‘Spotlight’

Journalists Walter Robinson, Marty Baron, Sacha Pfeiffer, Ben Bradlee Jr., Michael Rezendes and Matt Carroll, on whom Spotlight is based.

‘Janis: Little Girl Blue’

Writer-director Amy Berg of documentary Janis: Little Girl Blue, which talks to Janis Joplin intimates and delves into personal letters and scrapbooks.

Read the review

‘Being Charlie’

Common, Devon Bostick, Ricardo Chavira, Morgan Saylor, Susan Misner, Nick Robinson, Rob Reiner, Cary Elwes, Matt Elisofon and Nick Reiner of Being Charlie, following an 18-year-old who breaks out of a youth drug treatment clinic, but when he returns home to Los Angeles, he's given an intervention by his parents and forced to go to an adult rehab. There, he meets a girl and is forced to battle with drugs, elusive love and divided parents.

Read the review

‘Being Charlie’

Nick Robinson of Being Charlie.

‘Being Charlie’

Rob Reiner, director of Being Charlie.

See more TIFF: ‘Being Charlie’ Star Common Says We All Know Someone "Who's Dealt With Addiction"

‘Being Charlie’

Cary Elwes of Being Charlie.

See more TIFF: ‘Being Charlie’ Star Common Says We All Know Someone "Who's Dealt With Addiction"

‘Being Charlie’

Susan Misner of Being Charlie.

‘Being Charlie’

"The family members of people dealing with addiction also go through certain experiences, so to see the story from different perspectives was really insightful for me," said Common of Being Charlie.

See more TIFF: ‘Being Charlie’ Star Common Says We All Know Someone "Who's Dealt With Addiction"

‘Being Charlie’

Devon Bostick of Being Charlie.

See more TIFF: ‘Being Charlie’ Star Common Says We All Know Someone "Who's Dealt With Addiction"

‘Being Charlie’

Morgan Saylor of Being Charlie.

See more TIFF: ‘Being Charlie’ Star Common Says We All Know Someone "Who's Dealt With Addiction"

‘Being Charlie’

Morgan Saylor and Nick Robinson of Being Charlie.

‘Being Charlie’

Writers Matt Elisofon and Nick Reiner of Being Charlie.

See more TIFF: ‘Being Charlie’ Star Common Says We All Know Someone "Who's Dealt With Addiction"

‘Being Charlie’

Ricardo Chavira of Being Charlie.

Sony Pictures Classics

Sony Pictures Classics co-presidents Tom Bernard and Michael Barker.

See more TIFF: Sony Pictures Classics Presidents Say “Theaters Are Very Competitive”

Sony Pictures Classics

Sony Pictures Classics co-president Tom Bernard.

See more TIFF: Sony Pictures Classics Presidents Say “Theaters Are Very Competitive”

‘Love’

Director Gaspar Noe and Karl Glusman of Love.

’11 Minutes’

11 Minutes writer-director Jerzy Skolimowski.

‘Room’

Joan Allen, screenwriter Emma Donoghue, Jacob Tremblay, Brie Larson and director Lenny Abrahamson of Room, which zooms in on as a mother forced to raise her child in a single room.

Read the review

‘Room’

Brie Larson of Room.

See more TIFF: Brie Larson on the Making of Captivity Drama 'Room'

‘Room’

Jacob Tremblay of Room.

See more TIFF: Brie Larson on the Making of Captivity Drama 'Room'

‘Room’

Author-screenwriter Emma Donoghue of Room.

‘The Girl in the Photographs’

Luke Baines, director Nick Simon, Kal Penn, Claudia Lee, producer Thomas Mahoney and Miranda Rae Mayo of the quirky suburban slasher The Girl in the Photographs,

Read the review

‘The Girl in the Photographs’

Claudia Lee of The Girl in the Photographs.

‘The Girl in the Photographs’

Director Nick Simon said of making the film with his mentor Wes Craven, "As a filmmaker who has not done a lot, it’s the thing you daydream about — a legend who helps you make a movie."

Read more TIFF: Why Wes Craven's Spirit Lives On in 'The Girl in the Photographs'

‘The Girl in the Photographs’

Miranda Rae Mayo of The Girl in the Photographs.

‘The Girl in the Photographs’

Kal Penn of The Girl in the Photographs.

‘Septembers of Shiraz’

Shohreh Aghdashloo, director Wayne Blair, Salma Hayek and Alon Aboutboul of Septembers of Shiraz, following Iranian Jews endangered by the new regime after the fall of the Shah.

Read the review

‘Septembers of Shiraz’

Shohreh Aghdashloo of Septembers of Shiraz.

See more TIFF: ‘Septembers of Shiraz’ Star Salma Hayek Says "Humanity Is Not Not Black and White"

‘Septembers of Shiraz’

Alon Aboutboul of Septembers of Shiraz.

See more TIFF: ‘Septembers of Shiraz’ Star Salma Hayek Says "Humanity Is Not Not Black and White"

‘The Girl in the Photographs’

Luke Baines of The Girl in the Photographs.

‘Mississippi Grand’

Directors Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck of Mississippi Grand.

‘Anomalisa’

Tom Noonan, David Thewlis and Jennifer Jason Leigh of Anomalisa, an animated account of one man's long dark night of the soul pierced by light.

Read the review

‘Anomalisa’

Charlie Kaufman and Duke Johnson, co-writers and directors of Anomalisa.

‘Anomalisa’

Tom Noonan of Anomalisa.

tk

tk

‘Room’

Room director Lenny Abrahamson.

See more TIFF: Brie Larson on the Making of Captivity Drama 'Room'

‘Septembers of Shiraz’

Wayne Blair, director of Septembers of Shiraz.

‘Black Mass’

Dakota Johnson of Black Mass.

‘Room’

Joan Allen of Room.

‘Septembers of Shiraz’

Salma Hayek of Septembers of Shiraz.

‘Anomalisa’

Jennifer Jason Leigh of Anomalisa.

Sutherlands

Four Sutherlands descended on the festival this year: Donald and Kiefer with the father-son Western Forsaken and Rossif with a pair of drama, Hyena Road and River. But Roeg, co-head of CAA’s film finance and sales group, took the family prize for most TIFF projects, representing 19 finished films at the festival.
